text: The impediment to action advances action. What stands in the way becomes the way.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Waste no more time arguing what a good man should be. Be one.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: You have power over your mind—not outside events. Realize this, and you will find strength.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: We suffer more often in imagination than in reality.
author: Seneca

text: Luck is what happens when preparation meets opportunity.
author: Seneca

text: If a man knows not to which port he sails, no wind is favorable.
author: Seneca

text: It’s not what happens to you, but how you react to it that matters.
author: Epictetus

text: First say to yourself what you would be; and then do what you have to do.
author: Epictetus

text: No man is free who is not master of himself.
author: Epictetus

text: The best revenge is not to be like your enemy.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Difficulties strengthen the mind, as labor does the body.
author: Seneca

text: He has the most who is content with the least.
author: Diogenes

text: Character is destiny.
author: Heraclitus

text: One cannot step twice in the same river.
author: Heraclitus

text: The unexamined life is not worth living.
author: Socrates

text: Be as you wish to seem.
author: Socrates

text: Silence is a lesson learned through life’s many sufferings.
author: Seneca

text: Man conquers the world by conquering himself.
author: Zeno of Citium

text: It is not that we have a short time to live, but that we waste much of it.
author: Seneca

text: Wealth consists not in having great possessions, but in having few wants.
author: Epictetus

text: No man ever steps in the same river twice, for it’s not the same river and he’s not the same man.
author: Heraclitus

text: Knowing yourself is the beginning of all wisdom.
author: Aristotle

text: The happiness of your life depends upon the quality of your thoughts.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: It is not what we endure, but how we endure it, that makes us who we are.
author: Seneca

text: The greatest wealth is to live content with little.
author: Plato

text: He suffers more than necessary, who suffers before it is necessary.
author: Seneca

text: Don’t explain your philosophy. Embody it.
author: Epictetus
